questions.text: An X-ray of the thoracic spine demonstrates vertebra plana, characterized by complete flattening of the vertebral body and loss of normal vertebral body height. There is no evidence of traumatic injury. What is the most likely diagnosis?
What is the principle of TENS which is used for alleviating pain around joints and nerve pain?
questions.correct_answer: A. Gate theory of pain control
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Gate theory of pain control

questions.text: Meyer pedicle graft used for:

options.label: A
options.text: Fracture through neck of the talus

options.label: C
options.text: Fracture through the waist of the scaphoid

questions.correct_answer: B. Non-union fracture neck of femur
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Non-union fracture neck of femur

Explanation:

  • • Explanation: Talus fractures are managed with techniques that address the specific concerns of blood supply and bone healing in the talus. Meyer pedicle grafts are not specifically indicated for talar neck fractures.
  • • Explanation:
  • • Option C. Fracture through the waist of the scaphoid:
  • • Option
  • • C. Fracture through the waist of the scaphoid:
  • • Definition: The scaphoid is one of the carpal bones in the wrist. A fracture through the waist of the scaphoid is a common injury that can be complicated by issues such as avascular necrosis due to the limited blood supply to the bone.
  • • Definition: The scaphoid is one of the carpal bones in the wrist. A fracture through the waist of the scaphoid is a common injury that can be complicated by issues such as avascular necrosis due to the limited blood supply to the bone.
  • • Definition:
  • • Treatment:
  • • Treatment:
  • • Treatment:
  • • Immediate Management: Typically involves immobilization in a cast or splint. In cases of non-union or delayed union, surgical interventions such as bone grafting might be used. Grafting: Vascularized bone grafts or other techniques are used, but Meyer pedicle graft is not specifically indicated for scaphoid fractures.
  • • Immediate Management: Typically involves immobilization in a cast or splint. In cases of non-union or delayed union, surgical interventions such as bone grafting might be used.
  • • Immediate Management:
  • • Grafting: Vascularized bone grafts or other techniques are used, but Meyer pedicle graft is not specifically indicated for scaphoid fractures.
  • • Grafting:
  • • Explanation: For scaphoid fractures, especially those with non-union, other types of bone grafts or vascularized bone flaps are generally used rather than the Meyer pedicle graft.
  • • Explanation: For scaphoid fractures, especially those with non-union, other types of bone grafts or vascularized bone flaps are generally used rather than the Meyer pedicle graft.
  • • Explanation:
  • • Option D. Inter-trochanteric fracture of femur
  • • Option
  • • D. Inter-trochanteric fracture of femur
  • • Definition: An inter-trochanteric fracture is a type of fracture in the femur that occurs between the greater and lesser trochanters. This is a common fracture, especially in elderly patients, often resulting from falls. Treatment:
  • • Definition: An inter-trochanteric fracture is a type of fracture in the femur that occurs between the greater and lesser trochanters. This is a common fracture, especially in elderly patients, often resulting from falls.
  • • Definition:
  • • Treatment:
  • • Treatment:
  • • Immediate Management: Typically involves surgical fixation with plates or intramedullary nails to stabilize the fracture. Grafting: For simple inter-trochanteric fractures, grafting is generally not required unless there is a non-union or complex healing problem.
  • • Immediate Management: Typically involves surgical fixation with plates or intramedullary nails to stabilize the fracture.
  • • Immediate Management:
  • • Grafting: For simple inter-trochanteric fractures, grafting is generally not required unless there is a non-union or complex healing problem.
  • • Grafting:
  • • Explanation: Inter-trochanteric fractures are usually managed with internal fixation rather than specific bone grafting techniques like the Meyer pedicle graft.
  • • Explanation: Inter-trochanteric fractures are usually managed with internal fixation rather than specific bone grafting techniques like the Meyer pedicle graft.
  • • Explanation:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Meyer pedicle graft is specifically designed to address non-union fractures in the neck of the femur by providing a vascularized segment of bone to promote healing.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with rickets is on calcium supplements and has a foot deformity. The child will be referred to a surgeon for the correction of the deformity when:

options.label: B
options.text: Serum vitamin D levels are normal

questions.correct_answer: C. Growth plate healing becomes normal
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Growth plate healing becomes normal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The appropriate timing for surgical intervention based on the normalization of growth plate healing rather than relying solely on normal serum calcium, vitamin D levels, or alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • ➤ The appropriate timing for surgical intervention based on the normalization of growth plate healing rather than relying solely on normal serum calcium, vitamin D levels, or alkaline phosphatase levels.

questions.text: In Rickets, all are seen except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bleeding

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bleeding is not typically associated with rickets. Rickets primarily affects bone development and mineralization due to nutritional deficiencies, and bleeding is not a direct consequence of this condition. The clinical features of rickets are mainly related to bone deformities, weakness, and abnormalities in the growth plates.
  • ➤ Bleeding is not typically associated with rickets.
  • ➤ Rickets primarily affects bone development and mineralization due to nutritional deficiencies, and bleeding is not a direct consequence of this condition.
  • ➤ The clinical features of rickets are mainly related to bone deformities, weakness, and abnormalities in the growth plates.

questions.text: What causes both destruction of bone and reduction of joint space?
A patient presented with the following x-ray after an RTA. Diagnose the fracture:
Which of the following is not an aggressive periosteal reaction?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Thick and irregular

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Spiculated: Spiculated periosteal reactions are aggressive reactions, commonly seen in malignant lesions like osteosarcoma as sunray appearance.
  • • Option A. Spiculated:
  • • aggressive
  • • Option B. Laminated: Lamellated are aggressive reactions that are seen in malignant or chronic lesions like chronic osteomyelitis, ewing’s sarcoma as onion peel appearance.
  • • Option B. Laminated:
  • • aggressive
  • • Option D. Interrupted: Interrupted type of periosteal reaction is seen when the periosteum cannot produce new bone as fast as the growth of the lesion.
  • • Option D. Interrupted:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • These categories are not synonymous with benign and malignant, as there are benign entities capable of inducing aggressive periosteal reaction (e.g., infection and Langerhans cell histiocytosis) and numerous malignant entities that more commonly manifest with either nonaggressive periosteal.

questions.text: A child presented with the following deformity and history of recurrent tooth abscess. On lab investigation, his serum calcium was normal, serum phosphorus was normal/reduced, serum PTH was normal, and ALP was increased. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hypophosphatemic Rickets:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The normal serum calcium, normal or reduced serum phosphorus, normal PTH, and increased ALP, the diagnosis most consistent with these findings is hypophosphatemic rickets .
  • ➤ hypophosphatemic rickets

questions.text: Earliest way to detect development of compartment syndrome by a nurse in a patient with cast is:

options.label: A
options.text: Check radial pulse by displacing the cast

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy was brought to the ER following a motor vehicle collision, complaining of pain over the hip. The x-ray is given below. What is the next step of management?

options.label: A
options.text: Closed reduction and assessment of hip stability

options.label: D
options.text: Open reduction and posterior pillar of acetabulum reconstruction

questions.correct_answer: A. Closed reduction and assessment of hip stability
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Closed reduction and assessment of hip stability

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Closed Reduction and Assessment of Hip Stability is the most appropriate approach and is crucial for addressing potential dislocations or less complex fractures initially. Closed Reduction is typically the first line of treatment for dislocated hips or simple fractures. Assessment of Hip Stability ensures that the joint is properly aligned and stable, reducing the risk of complications.

questions.correct_answer: B. Pathological fracture due to non-ossifying fibroma
questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Non-ossifying fibromas are common in this age group, often asymptomatic until they lead to a fracture.

Which nerve was most likely damaged?

options.label: B
options.text: Posterior cutaneous nerve of the forearm

questions.correct_answer: D. Superficial branch of the radial nerve

questions.text: All of the following cause erosive arthritis except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lupus arthritis/Jaccoud arthritis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Rheumatoid arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic autoimmune disorder that primarily affects the joints. Rheumatoid Arthritis is known for causing erosive arthritis, as chronic inflammation in the synovium leads to the destruction of cartilage and bone within the joints.
  • • Option A. Rheumatoid arthritis:
  • • Option C. Tuberculous arthritis: Tuberculous arthritis, caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, can lead to joint destruction. It can cause erosive arthritis.
  • • Option C. Tuberculous arthritis:
  • • Option D. Septic arthritis: Septic arthritis is caused by a bacterial infection within a joint, leading to inflammation and potential joint damage.
  • • Option D. Septic arthritis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lupus Arthritis/Jaccoud arthritis does not cause erosive arthritis. Lupus arthritis, also known as Jaccoud arthritis , is a form of arthritis associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), an autoimmune disease. Jaccoud arthritis is generally considered non-erosive inflammatory arthritis. It involves joint deformities that are reversible and does not typically result in erosive changes.
  • ➤ Lupus Arthritis/Jaccoud arthritis does not cause erosive arthritis.
  • ➤ Lupus arthritis, also known as Jaccoud arthritis , is a form of arthritis associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), an autoimmune disease.
  • ➤ Jaccoud arthritis
  • ➤ Jaccoud arthritis is generally considered non-erosive inflammatory arthritis.
  • ➤ It involves joint deformities that are reversible and does not typically result in erosive changes.

questions.text: A 71-year-old female recently had coronary bypass surgery in which the small saphenous vein was harvested to establish coronary blood flow.
